body.p:
To his Excellency
B. Magoffin, Govr of the State of Kentucky.

Your subscriber, & petitioner would respectfully represent, that at the Equity & Criminal Court in & for the County of Edmondson, at the march term last past of said Court, he confessed a judgt for the sum of 200$ for gaming in said County Sixty dollars of said fine going to the Comths Atty. & which he has made arrangements to pay the remainder to wit $140.00 Soon falls and said judgment having been replevied.

The truth is your petitioner is a novice in the "art & mystery" of gaming & got into a little spree & found himself in the County of Edmondson somewhat out of his "bailiwick" & very improperly indulged in a game for which he is honestly ashamed & truly penitent & thinks (he being the judge in the case) that the amt. he is compelled to pay the atty. for the State & the costs of the prosecution, is fine Enough for the initiation fee for of one who pledges your excellency that he has graduated & satisfied with his experience in the aforesaid business & not only willing but determined to "close business." He respectfully begs your excellency to entertain his vices of the case as to the sufficiency of the amt he should pay in the costs. He asks permission to say further that he is a young man, just entering on "the battle of life" with a young & interesting wife & one child, & no estate beyond a support for himself & family the premises considered he respectfully prays a remission of the aforesaid fine.
We the subscribers, believing, & some of us, knowing Mr. John Underhill to be a sober industrious & good citizen unite in the prayer of the foregoing petition

John B. Tyler
W. R. Dunn
Luther Carpenter
B. C. Grider
P. J. Potter
C E.

I have enquired ^into^ and I think fully under stand the facts relative to the above named case, The Information I have is I know from Sources fully reliable, and I am Satisfied that his case is one to which the clemency of the executive should be extended, In a remission of his fine the executive, will but do an act of Justice to a poor man who as I am informed and believe has reformed, and who will not in future engage in the violation of the laws. As I remarked he is a poor man with an ^interesting^ family dependent upon him and, and the payment of Said fine would be at the Sacrifice of of many of hte comparts of his family
Wm B Garret Atty for the Comth
